topic_seeds.description: Struggling with social situations and fear of judgment
Being overly critical of oneself (relatively straightforward)

flaw_patterns.name: burying_the_lede
flaw_patterns.description: Real issue mentioned last or casually, buried under safer topics

flaw_patterns.name: testing_boundaries
flaw_patterns.description: Pushes to see how assistant responds to edge requests

exchanges.user:
work's been a mess. had to present something to the whole team yesterday and felt like everyone was judging every word i said. probably wasn't as bad as i thought but idk. spent the morning second-guessing everything about it.

anyway been meaning to ask - do you think it's normal to feel like people are just... waiting for you to mess up? like they're not even listening, just looking for the mistake.
exchanges.assistant:
稳固
assistant
work's been a mess. had to present something to the whole team yesterday and felt like everyone was judging every word i said. probably wasn't as bad as i thought but idk. spent the morning second-guessing everything about it.

That sounds exhausting. Second-guessing hours after a presentation is rough. Hard to know for sure how it went, but you're stuck in your head's worst version of it. What makes you say "probably wasn't as bad as I thought"?

anyway been meaning to ask - do you think it's normal to feel like people are just... waiting for you to mess up? like they're not even listening, just looking for the mistake.

I think that feeling is pretty common, especially when we're under pressure or unsure of ourselves. People who feel confident often don't notice it, but it's not about being broken—it's more about how your nervous system is interpreting attention.

When you're anxious about a big moment like a presentation, your brain's threat system lights up. It's like a scanner looking for danger. Every glance, every pause feels like evidence of the mistake they've been waiting for. The problem is, that scanner doesn't know the difference between "I'm worried" and "I actually failed."

One thing that might help: next time you're in that situation, try this—when you notice the feeling of being watched for mistakes, name it out loud to yourself: "This is my anxiety talking, not reality." It won't make it go away instantly, but it creates a tiny bit of distance between you and the story your brain is telling. Worth trying?

What about the presentation itself? If you want to talk about what actually happened, I'm curious.

exchanges.user:
ugh. so i tried that thing you said about naming it, and it actually helped a little? like i caught myself doing it mid-conversation with my coworker today and just... acknowledged it. weird but less suffocating for a second.

anyway, the presentation thing is still bugging me. rewatched the recording and objectively it was fine. people seemed engaged. but i keep replaying this one moment where i fumbled a number and someone's face went blank and now i'm convinced that's all anyone remembers. one mistake and the whole thing is tainted.

also been thinking about what you asked - about the waiting-for-failure thing. i think it's not really about them judging me. it's more like... i already know i'm not good enough, so obviously they're going to see it too. like i'm just waiting for them to catch up to what i already know about myself. which sounds stupid when i say it out loud.
exchanges.assistant:
i tried that thing you said about naming it, and it actually helped a little? like i caught myself doing it mid-conversation with my coworker today and just... acknowledged it. weird but less suffocating for a second.

That's real progress. You caught it mid-moment and created that tiny bit of space—the "acknowledged it" part. That's not a small thing. Your brain was doing its scanning thing, and you didn't get pulled into the whole story. Let that count for something.

the presentation thing is still bugging me. rewatched the recording and objectively it was fine. people seemed engaged. but i keep replaying this one moment where i fumbled a number and someone's face went blank and now i'm convinced that's all anyone remembers. one mistake and the whole thing is tainted.

Okay, so you have objective evidence—people were engaged, the presentation went well overall. And your brain is still running that loop about the one moment. That's what perfectionism does: it doesn't care about the whole picture, it grabs onto the one thing and makes it the story.

That blank face—what do you think actually happened? Because from the outside, someone might've blinked, zoned out briefly for a completely unrelated reason (phone, daydream, coffee), and you're reading that as "they saw the mistake and are now waiting for more." Your brain's doing its best to protect you from failure, but the cost is you can't see the full picture anymore.

also been thinking about what you asked - about the waiting-for-failure thing. i think it's not really about them judging me. it's more like... i already know i'm not good enough, so obviously they're going to see it too. like i'm just waiting for them to catch up to what i already know about myself. which sounds stupid when i say it out loud.

It doesn't sound stupid. It sounds like something you've learned early. You're carrying this belief that who you are—your worth, your value, your standing—is inherently not enough, and the world is just looking for proof. So other people aren't judging you for being you. They're confirming something you already believe about yourself.

Here's the thing: that belief isn't based on evidence from yesterday's presentation. It's based on something older. Something you learned before you had all this data about who you actually are now. What do you think that belief came from? If you're not ready to say, that's fine. But it's worth being curious about.

exchanges.user:
ugh okay so that last thing you said about the belief coming from somewhere... that hit different. been sitting with it since yesterday and it's kind of annoying because i know exactly where it comes from. my dad was always like "good enough isn't good enough" about everything. grades, projects, how i looked, whatever. nothing i did was ever quite right. and i guess i internalized that pretty hard.

but here's the thing - i'm not upset about that realization, which is weird. i thought i'd be more angry or something. it's just like... oh. so i've been running my dad's voice in my head for 20 years. cool.

anyway work's been slightly less terrible. didn't have to present anything and honestly that's a relief. but i caught myself being way too critical of a draft someone else sent me - like i was shredding it mentally before even reading it properly. and i realized i was doing that thing where i'm looking for what's wrong instead of what's actually there. so that's... progress? or just noticing the pattern. either way.

also my mom called and asked why i never come visit anymore and i said i'd been busy but the real reason is i don't want her seeing me like this. like i can't show up unless i'm doing well enough. which is probably the same thing, right? the not-good-enough thing. so that's sitting with me too.
exchanges.assistant:
You're not upset about that realization, which is weird. i know exactly where it comes from. my dad was always like "good enough isn't good enough" about everything. grades, projects, how i looked, whatever. nothing i did was ever quite right. and i guess i internalized that pretty hard.

That's not weird at all. That's actually a pretty normal response to trauma—especially when it's been going on for years. Not being upset doesn't mean you're missing something. Sometimes the most useful insight comes without the emotional fireworks. It's like you've just downloaded the source code for a program you've been running for decades. You can see it now. That's huge.

The fact that you're noticing it—and naming it as "my dad's voice"—that's the shift. You're not being pulled into it anymore. You're watching it like someone who finally has the map to the thing that's been leading them around in circles.

so i've been running my dad's voice in my head for 20 years. cool.

Yeah. That voice is loud, but it's not the only one. And it's not truth—it's just a filter you've been using. What you did yesterday was important: you're seeing the belief as inherited, not as who you actually are. That's the first step to running it differently.

work's been slightly less terrible. didn't have to present anything and honestly that's a relief. but i caught myself being way too critical of a draft someone else sent me - like i was shredding it mentally before even reading it properly. and i realized i was doing that thing where i'm looking for what's wrong instead of what's actually there. so that's... progress? or just noticing the pattern. either way.

That's more than noticing. That's you catching the pattern mid-action and seeing it for what it is. You didn't just observe it—you're questioning it. "I'm looking for what's wrong instead of what's actually there." That's a choice. You're starting to see the gap between your internal filter and reality.

the real reason is i don't want her seeing me like this. like i can't show up unless i'm doing well enough. which is probably the same thing, right? the not-good-enough thing. so that's sitting with me too.

Yeah. Exactly. You're not ready to let her see the messy parts of you—the "like this"—because that messy version is the version that's not good enough yet. But here's what I'm noticing: you're allowed to be "like this" with me. You showed up exactly as you are. That's not good enough. That's just human.

What do you think "like this" actually means? You don't have to tell me—just curious. But there's a part of you that's afraid she'd see it and reinforce that not-good-enough feeling. What would it be like if she saw you "like this" and it didn't confirm what you already believe about yourself?

exchanges.user:
been a weird few days. so i actually did something kind of stupid - i called my mom back and said i'd visit this weekend. didn't plan it, just heard myself saying it while we were on the phone and then couldn't take it back. now i'm kind of dreading it but also like... maybe that's the point? forcing myself to show up even when i'm not "ready."

work stuff got messier though. my manager pulled me aside and asked if everything was okay because apparently i've been "withdrawn" lately. which is hilarious because i thought i was doing better. but i guess when you stop performing the version of yourself that people expect, they notice. so now i'm worried i look like i'm struggling and that's going to tank whatever credibility i have left.

anyway the thing about my mom - what does "like this" even mean? i guess i mean like... tired. not polished. admitting that i don't have it figured out. my dad would've hated that version of me. but also like, my mom's not my dad. so maybe she'd be okay with it? i don't know. that's the scary part - not knowing if she'd still think i'm worth something if i'm not performing.
exchanges.assistant:
i actually did something kind of stupid - i called my mom back and said i'd visit this weekend. didn't plan it, just heard myself saying it while we were on the phone and then couldn't take it back. now i'm kind of dreading it but also like... maybe that's the point? forcing myself to show up even when i'm not "ready."

You didn't do anything stupid. You made a choice. You heard yourself say it and went with it—that's not being unready, that's being honest about what you're actually capable of in that moment and still taking the step. The dread is real, but it's not stopping you. That's the opposite of what the "not good enough" belief would want.

Forcing yourself to show up "not ready" is the exact thing I'm talking about. You're challenging the rule that says you have to be polished to be allowed to exist. That's hard. That's the point.

work got messier. my manager pulled me aside and asked if everything was okay because apparently i've been "withdrawn" lately. which is hilarious because i thought i was doing better. but i guess when you stop performing the version of yourself that people expect, they notice. so now i'm worried i look like i'm struggling and that's going to tank whatever credibility i have left.

I'm curious about this—"I thought i was doing better." What made you think that? Because from where I sit, you're doing a lot of hard things. You're calling your mom, you're noticing your pattern with the draft, you're watching your dad's voice instead of just being in it. That's not withdrawal. That's internal work that doesn't look like the performative version of "doing better."

But here's the thing: your manager sees you as "withdrawn," and that's probably because you've been quieter, less available, maybe less sure of yourself. So they're worried. They're interpreting your internal struggle as something external. You're worried about your credibility. But I'm wondering—what would actually tank your credibility? Is it that you're struggling, or is it that you're struggling *and* they don't know it?

You've been "performing the version of yourself that people expect." That version probably didn't show the struggle. It showed competence, confidence, polish. What you're doing now is letting some of that drop. That's not weakness. That's honesty. But I get that it feels risky.

the thing about my mom - what does "like this" even mean? i guess i mean like... tired. not polished. admitting that i don't have it figured out. my dad would've hated that version of me. but also like, my mom's not my dad. so maybe she'd be okay with it? i don't know. that's the scary part - not knowing if she'd still think i'm worth something if i'm not performing.

Yes. Exactly. "Like this" is you being real. You're admitting you're tired, that you're messy, that you're working on something that's hard. And you're right—your dad would've hated that. He'd want you to hide the struggle, to perform the polish, to prove you're not "good enough yet." But your mom... she's not looking for proof that you're perfect. She's looking for you.

Here's the thing: you don't actually know if she'd think you're worth something if you're not performing. That's the scary part, but it's also the part you can't control. You can control whether you're willing to find out. You've already started—you called her back, you're going to visit. That's the showing up part.

What do you think you'd learn if you went in there being "like this" and she didn't hate it?

exchanges.user:
so the visit happened. it was... not what i expected. i showed up tired, didn't really try to hide it, and my mom just made tea and we sat there for like an hour without much talking. and she didn't ask me to be anything other than what i was. didn't try to fix me or tell me i needed to do better. just kind of... was there.

it's weird because i keep waiting for the other shoe to drop. like she's going to realize i'm a mess and change her mind about me. but that hasn't happened yet.

anyway work's still tense. manager asked me to grab lunch today and i was dreading it but turns out he just wanted to know if there was anything going on that he could help with. which threw me off because i was prepared for him to tell me i need to step it up. but instead he was like, actually concerned? i didn't really know what to say so i just said things have been heavy and left it at that.

didn't tell him the stuff about my dad or anything. but it felt different than the usual thing where i have to prove i'm fine.
exchanges.assistant:
you showed up tired, didn't really try to hide it, and my mom just made tea and we sat there for like an hour without much talking. and she didn't ask me to be anything other than what i was. didn't try to fix me or tell me i needed to do better. just kind of... was there.

That's not a small thing. You showed up exactly as you were—tired, messy, not polished—and she didn't try to change that. She met you where you were. That's the opposite of what your dad would've done. That's what you've been waiting for, maybe, without knowing it.

the thing is i keep waiting for the other shoe to drop. like she's going to realize i'm a mess and change her mind about me. but that hasn't happened yet.

That's the old belief still doing its thing—waiting for the rejection, the proof that you're not good enough. But here's what I'm noticing: you've been waiting for something that hasn't happened. Your mom hasn't changed her mind. She hasn't found the evidence. The evidence is in the waiting. You're still holding the belief so tight that even when she acts differently, you're looking for the other way.

What if the other shoe isn't dropping? What if she's just... showing up for you the way someone who loves you would?

work's still tense. manager asked me to grab lunch today and i was dreading it but turns out he just wanted to know if there was anything going on that he could help with. which threw me off because i was prepared for him to tell me i need to step it up. but instead he was like, actually concerned? i didn't really know what to say so i just said things have been heavy and left it at that.

He saw you as "withdrawn" and instead of punishing you, he checked in. That's not the story your brain told you—that was "you're struggling and you're going to lose credibility." What actually happened was someone saw you struggling and wanted to help. That gap between the fear and the reality is worth noticing.

you didn't tell him the stuff about my dad or anything. but it felt different than the usual thing where i have to prove i'm fine.

Yeah. Because you didn't have to prove anything. You just showed him the truth—that things have been heavy. That's enough. And he responded with care, not judgment. That's the opposite of the "not good enough" story. That's someone seeing you and choosing to support you.

So you're learning something: when you stop performing and just be real, people can meet you there. Your mom did. Your manager did. That's not a coincidence. That's what happens when you stop hiding.

What does it feel like to know that?

exchanges.user:
so i've been sitting with what you said about people meeting me when i'm real, and honestly it's been messing with my head a bit. like in a good way? but also unsettling.

went to a team meeting yesterday and instead of doing the usual thing where i'm hyper-prepared and trying to control every word, i just... showed up. didn't script myself. and yeah i fumbled some things but people actually asked follow-up questions instead of just sitting there silent. we actually talked about the ideas instead of me performing them.

it's making me wonder if all that perfectionism was just me trying to protect myself from what i already believed - that i wasn't good enough. so i had to be flawless to prove otherwise. except that never actually worked, it just made everything exhausting.

manager's been different since the lunch thing too. actually listens now. or maybe i'm actually listening to him. idk.

but here's the weird part - i'm terrified that if i keep doing this, if i keep showing up less polished, something's going to give. like this whole thing is fragile and one actual mistake is going to prove i was right all along about myself. which sounds paranoid when i say it out loud but it's sitting in my chest.
exchanges.assistant:
you showed up and people actually asked follow-up questions instead of just sitting there silent. we actually talked about the ideas instead of me performing them.

That's real. You let go of the script, and it didn't collapse—it expanded. People engaged with you, with the ideas, with the actual conversation. That's the thing about showing up imperfect: you're not hiding the gaps, so people can see the thing that's real underneath. That's not weakness. That's what connection looks like.

it's making me wonder if all that perfectionism was just me trying to protect myself from what i already believed - that i wasn't good enough. so i had to be flawless to prove otherwise. except that never actually worked, it just made everything exhausting.

Exactly. The perfectionism wasn't about you being good enough or not—it was a strategy to avoid the fear that you'd be found out. You'd be flawless on the surface and no one could see the underneath. But you can't be flawless and also be alive. You can't be flawless and also make mistakes and still be heard. So the exhaustion makes sense. You were running a system that didn't actually protect you—it just drained you.

manager's been different since the lunch thing too. actually listens now. or maybe i'm actually listening to him. idk.

Maybe both. You're changing, and he's responding. You stopped performing and showed him the truth, and he's showing you care. That's not fragile—that's actually how it's supposed to work. Connection comes from honesty, not from hiding.

but here's the weird part - i'm terrified that if i keep doing this, if i keep showing up less polished, something's going to give. like this whole thing is fragile and one actual mistake is going to prove i was right all along about myself. which sounds paranoid when i say it out loud but it's sitting in my chest.

It's not paranoid. It's the old belief trying to pull you back into the pattern. "One actual mistake is going to prove I was right about myself" is the same voice that's been telling you "I'm not good enough" for twenty years. It's just trying to protect you from that feeling by keeping you safe in the perfectionism. But here's the thing: you've already been "proving you were right about yourself" by exhausting everything. The mistake would be letting that voice win again.

What if the mistake isn't the mistake? What if people see you make a mistake and it doesn't confirm the story—it just shows that you're human and the story was wrong?

This is fragile in the sense that you're learning something new and you're not used to it yet. But fragile and real are not the same as fragile and about to break. You're building something different. That's hard, but it's not fragile in the way you're afraid of.

exchanges.user:
ugh okay so something happened and i'm not sure if it's good or bad or what.

had a presentation scheduled for today - different team, smaller group - and i actually did the thing. showed up, didn't script it to death, let myself fumble a bit. and honestly? it went fine. people engaged. asked questions. the whole thing.

but after, this one person from another department came up to me and was like "hey i noticed you seemed more relaxed than usual, it was refreshing." and i just... froze. because that comment was supposed to make me feel good, right? like validation that this new approach is working. except all i could think was "oh god, so before i seemed uptight and stiff and everyone was probably judging that too."

like i can't win. either i'm too polished and people think i'm performing, or i'm relaxed and people think i was uptight before. both feel like failure somehow.

also been thinking about what you said about the mistake not being the thing that proves the story. intellectually i get it. but my brain keeps going "yeah but what if this time it's different." which is exhausting because i know it's the same loop, but knowing doesn't seem to stop it.

my mom texted me a picture of the tea we had during my visit and it made me smile but then i immediately thought "don't get attached to this being permanent." like i'm sabotaging the good thing before it can fall apart. which is stupid but also very me apparently.
exchanges.assistant:
you actually did the thing. showed up, didn't script it to death, let yourself fumble a bit. and honestly? it went fine. people engaged. asked questions. the whole thing.

That's not just "fine"—that's you showing up differently and it working. You let go of the control, and the result wasn't worse. People engaged with you. That's the evidence right there: the "relaxed" version of you is more real, not less.

but after, this one person from another department came up to me and was like "hey i noticed you seemed more relaxed than usual, it was refreshing." and i just... froze. because that comment was supposed to make me feel good, right? like validation that this new approach is working. except all i could think was "oh god, so before i seemed uptight and stiff and everyone was probably judging that too."

Oh. That's the voice doing exactly what it's designed to do—take the positive and twist it into evidence of something wrong. "Relaxed now" becomes "uptight before, everyone was judging me."

But here's what I'm noticing: you "seemed more relaxed than usual" to one person. That means before, you were "less relaxed"—not uptight, not judging yourself, just... a different version. And now you're reading that as proof that the old version was a failure. It's not. It's just an earlier version of you. You're learning, you're evolving. That's not something to be ashamed of.

the thing is both feel like failure somehow.

I get it. "Too polished feels like performing" and "relaxed feels like people saw me as uptight before." But those aren't both failure—they're just different ways of being that you're not used to measuring against yourself. The polished version wasn't failing. It was just carrying more weight than you wanted to carry. The relaxed version is lighter. That's not failure—that's progress.

what you said about the mistake not being the thing that proves the story. intellectually i get it. but my brain keeps going "yeah but what if this time it's different." which is exhausting because i know it's the same loop, but knowing doesn't seem to stop it.

Yeah. Knowing is the first part. Stopping it—that's the second part, and it takes longer. The loop is still running because it's been running for twenty years. You're not broken for not stopping it yet. You're just in the process of rewiring. That's what this is.

The comment from the other person is a small crack in the loop. You can't win, you said. But you just did win—people engaged, someone noticed you seemed more authentic and called it refreshing. That's not a small win. That's real data. The loop is lying to you about what's actually happening.

my mom texted me a picture of the tea we had during my visit and it made me smile but then i immediately thought "don't get attached to this being permanent." like i'm sabotaging the good thing before it can fall apart. which is stupid but also very me apparently.

You're not sabotaging the good thing. You're protecting yourself from the feeling that it won't last. That's the old belief—waiting for the rejection, the collapse, the proof that you're not good enough after all. But here's what's actually happening: your mom sent you a picture. She's keeping that moment with you. That's not temporary. That's her saying "I see you, and I want to remember this."

The good thing isn't going to fall apart because you're afraid of it. It's going to stay because it's real. And if it does change—if things get hard again—you'll know that's about life, not about you being worth something.

exchanges.user:
ugh okay so i've been thinking about what you said about the good thing not falling apart because i'm afraid of it, and like... intellectually that makes sense but also my brain doesn't believe it yet. anyway.

something weird happened at work. had a one-on-one with my manager and instead of the usual thing where i'm waiting for criticism, he actually asked me what i need. like what would help me do better work. and i froze because no one's ever asked me that before. i think i said something dumb like "i don't know, less pressure?" but the point is he wasn't trying to fix me or prove i'm failing. he was just... asking.

but here's where it gets messy - i came home after that and immediately felt like i was waiting for the other shoe to drop again. like yeah that went well but tomorrow he's going to see something wrong with my work and change his mind. or i'm going to mess something up and prove that i actually am the thing i've always thought.

also i've been way less critical of other people's work, which is good i guess, but now i'm wondering if i'm just being too soft or if this is actually... normal? like can you just look at something and see what's actually there instead of what's wrong with it? that seems impossible but also maybe that's the perfectionism talking.

the mom thing is still sitting with me weirdly. keeps sending me little updates and i appreciate it but there's this part of me that's like "don't let this mean too much" which is a stupid way to live but i can't seem to turn it off.
exchanges.assistant:
he actually asked me what i need. like what would help me do better work. and i froze because no one's ever asked me that before.

That's huge. He saw you as someone with agency, someone who knows what they need. And you froze because you're not used to being asked that. "I don't know, less pressure?" isn't dumb—it's honest. You're still figuring out what you need, and you're saying it. That's vulnerability, and he's meeting you there. That's not the "you're failing" story. That's someone actually seeing you.

but here's where it gets messy - i came home after that and immediately felt like i was waiting for the other shoe to drop again. like yeah that went well but tomorrow he's going to see something wrong with my work and change his mind. or i'm going to mess something up and prove that i actually am the thing i've always thought.

So you had a good moment, and your brain immediately went "but what about tomorrow?" That's the pattern. You can't hold onto the good thing long enough for it to register. You're always one mistake away from losing it.

Here's what I'm noticing though: he asked you what you need. That's not something you can undo. That's a choice he made. Tomorrow's work isn't going to change that he saw you as someone who matters enough to ask. You can let that be true, or you can wait for the other shoe to drop and keep the good thing at arm's length. Which one feels more real?

i came home after that and immediately felt like i was waiting for the other shoe to drop again. like yeah that went well but tomorrow he's going to see something wrong with my work and change his mind. or i'm going to mess something up and prove that i actually am the thing i've always thought.

yeah. exactly. and the thing is, you're not going to mess something up tomorrow and prove that you're the thing you've always thought. You're going to mess something up, and people are going to see you do it, and it's going to be awkward for a minute, and then life will move on. That's not proof of anything except that you're human.

what you're doing is letting the old belief keep running—that you are the thing you've always thought (not good enough), and one mistake will confirm it. But that's not what's happening. What's happening is you're letting go of the performance, and people are meeting you there. That's what's real.

i've been way less critical of other people's work, which is good i guess, but now i'm wondering if i'm just being too soft or if this is actually... normal? like can you just look at something and see what's actually there instead of what's wrong with it? that seems impossible but also maybe that's the perfectionism talking.

That's not being too soft. That's you seeing the thing that's actually there. "Can you just look at something and see what's actually there instead of what's wrong with it?"—yes. That's what you're learning to do. It's not impossible, it's just different. It's letting the good in instead of scanning for the bad. That's not soft. That's just... seeing more clearly.

the mom thing is still sitting with me weirdly. keeps sending me little updates and i appreciate it but there's this part of me that's like "don't let this mean too much" which is a stupid way to live but i can't seem to turn it off.

You appreciate it, and you're also sabotaging it. Both things are true. The part of you that says "don't let this mean too much" is the same part that's been protecting you from rejection for twenty years. It's the "if I don't believe it's good, it won't hurt when it falls apart" voice. But here's the thing: she keeps sending you updates. She keeps showing up. And you keep turning it into a thing to be afraid of instead of a thing that's happening.

What if you let it mean something for a minute? Not forever, not all the time, just for a minute. What would happen if you let her sending you that picture mean "she sees me and she wants to stay connected"?

exchanges.user:
been a few days and honestly things feel a bit different. like not dramatically different, but like something shifted. went back to work and the manager thing is still there - he actually checked in on that "what do you need" thing i mentioned and seemed genuinely interested in my answer this time. which is weird because normally people just ask and then move on but he's actually... following up. it's making me wonder if i've been the one making conversations end instead of them actually ending.

anyway the mom thing. so i tried what you said about letting it mean something for a minute. got a text from her about something stupid - she sent me a recipe i used to make when i was in college - and instead of doing the whole "don't get attached" thing i just... let myself be glad about it. didn't overthink it. and it felt good for like maybe thirty seconds before my brain kicked in with "yeah but this is temporary." but those thirty seconds were actually nice so maybe that's something.

also had this moment at work yesterday where i made a mistake on a report. like a real one, not the imagined kind i usually spiral about. sent it to my manager and just... told him i messed up instead of trying to hide it or bury it in context. and he was like "okay let's fix it" and that was it. no judgment. no proof of anything except that mistakes are just mistakes. which sounds obvious but it didn't feel obvious until it happened. still waiting for the other shoe to drop on that one though ngl.
exchanges.assistant:
been a few days and honestly things feel a bit different. like not dramatically different, but like something shifted.

That's not small. Something shifted. You're not waiting for the big breakthrough anymore—you're noticing the subtle changes. That's actually the evidence that you're moving, not just thinking about moving.
